thread.title: Nature notes: autumn leaves its mark on our trees
thread.title_full: Nature notes: autumn leaves its mark on our trees - Telegraph

author: Hana Carter
title: Nature notes: autumn leaves its mark on our trees
text: Autumn has arrived and several species of trees are changing colour. The first to switch are some of our native trees such as the wild cherry, common spindle and dog wood. Autumnal leaves in Sidmouth, Devon Photo: Rex During the summer, leaves contain high levels of green chlorophyll which harnesses energy from sunlight to combine water and CO2 to create sugars, which feed the plant. In autumn, trees prepare for a shortage of light and water in winter and live off food that was stored in the summer. • Where to see autumn colours around the UK • Autumn colour around the UK, in pictures Gradually chlorophyll disappears from the leaves and other chemicals take over, such as carotene - the substance that gives a carrot its colour. These colours are in the leaves all year but were hidden by green chlorophyll. Japanese Maple trees at the Westonbirt Arboretum near Tetbury in Gloucestershire, pictured in October Photo: Stephen Lock/The Telegraph In some trees such as maple, glucose is trapped in the leaves after photosynthesis stops. Sunlight and the cool nights of autumn cause the leaves to turn this glucose red. telegraph.co.uk
